editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p:
HAuing fini≈øhed the tran≈ølation of this mo≈øt ≈øinguler and profitable worke (the commendation whereof I thinke altogither impertinent and needele≈ø≈øe for me in this place to handle, e≈øpecially, ≈øeeing the preface of the Author, and the iudgement of that mo≈øt learned and profounde Deuine, M. doctor Fulke prefixed and ≈øet before it, doe throughly and ≈øufficiently performe the ≈øame.) Entring into ≈øome con≈øideration with my ≈øelfe, vnto whome I might worthily dedicate and offer vp this my ≈øimple labour, ≈øuch as it is, (≈øimple I call it, not in regarde of the matter and ≈øub≈øtance of the worke, the which in this re≈øpect may verie well be≈øeeme the fauourable & gentle acceptation of the be≈øt, but in regarde of
mine owne ≈øimplicitie and plainne≈ø≈øe in tran≈ølation) I called to my remembrance (right wor≈øhipfull) the great and vnde≈øerued curte≈øie verie lately receiued at both your handes, the which being ≈øuch, as is not only priuately knowen vnto my ≈øelfe, but al≈øo publikely recorded in the memorie of manie other welwillers and wi≈øhers vnto you both, albeit that concerning your owne verie wor≈øhipfull and frindly natures, I doubted not but that you woulde right curteou≈øly accept of priuat thanks, where there wanteth abilitie of making de≈øerued recompence: yet could I not per≈øuade my ≈øelfe to goe cleare from ≈øu≈øpition of vnthankfulnes among others, if I ≈øhould not leaue ≈øome publike te≈øtimonie of my thankfulne≈ø≈øe for that benefite, which is publikely knowen to haue bin receiued. And albeit this way I ≈øtande chiefely beholding vnto the right wor≈øhipfull your louing and welbeloued ≈øonne in lawe, yet con≈øidering your wor≈øhipful approbation and good liking of his mo≈øt frindly curte≈øie extended towardes mee in the ≈øame, and al≈øo your owne friendly trauaile and labour to that effect: as I worthely acknowledge my ≈øelfe much bounde vnto you both, ≈øo I tru≈øt it ≈øhall not bee mi≈øliked in common thankfulne≈ø≈øe to haue ioyned two ≈øuch gentlemen togither, as be≈øides the neere band of con≈øanguinitie and affinitie, do for many other re≈øpectes the one ≈øo well like & loue the other. Accept therefore, I mo≈øt humbly
be≈øeech you, this ≈ømall token of mine vnfained and dutifull good will, proceeding from ≈øuch a one, who, though in worldly re≈øpectes he be not comparable vnto many, which account them ≈øelues many wayes bound and beholding vnto you, yet in all gratefull remembrance of ≈øuch ≈øurpa≈øsing kindne≈ø≈øe founde at your wor≈øhips handes would be loth to be exceede of any, of whome at any time you haue be≈øt de≈øerued. The Lorde ble≈ø≈øe and pre≈øerue both your good w. and all yours, and graunt you with them and others vnto who≈øe handes this my ≈øimple labour ≈øhall hereafter come, to reape ≈øuch frute thereby, as I by taking vpon me to fini≈øh and publi≈øh the ≈øame, haue vnfainedly wi≈øhed, and heartily hope for: to wit, that God may bee glorified, you edified, his Church and people in≈øtructed and profited in further knowledge and increa≈øe of his trueth, and in expre≈øsing the frutes of the ≈øame in a godly and holie conuer≈øation through Chri≈øt our Lord. div.head: Vnto the godly Chri≈øtian Reader.
div.p:
IN what account this worke is to be had, the learned in Diuinitie neede not to be admoni≈øhed. The text of holy Scripture being ≈øuch, as of it ≈øelfe de≈øerueth all reuerence: the Commentarie ≈øo framed, as a ta≈øte of it being taken, it will ea≈øily procure a good appetite to embrace the whole throughly. But that ≈øuch as be de≈øirous of heauenly wi≈øedome, and yet haue not attained to ≈øuch ripene≈ø≈øe of iudgement, as they can of them≈øelues di≈øcerne of bookes (that in the≈øe dayes are ≈øet forth in great numbers) which are mo≈øt for their profit, may bee put in minde of the excellencie of this treati≈øe to the furtherance of their godly ≈øtudie, I thought good, beeing thereto required, in fewe wordes to encourage them to vndertake the reading thereof to the ende they maye reape ≈øuch profite thereby, as may delight them for the pre≈øent, and the frute thereof remaine with them for euer. The wi≈øedome of God, in all the holy ≈øcripture in≈øpired of God, ≈øheweth it ≈øelfe, according to the matter whereof it entreateth, to be mo≈øt excellent. The argument of this ≈øermon being of wi≈øedome, vttered by that in≈øtrument of the holie Gho≈øt, whome God cho≈øe aboue all men (except him in whome all the trea≈øures of wi≈øedome are layd vp, our Sauiour Chri≈øt I meane) in whome hee would place the excellencie of vnder≈øtanding, about the attaining whereof all the
wi≈øe men of the worlde dulled their wittes in vaine: there mu≈øt needes be opened vnto vs thereby a certain and vndoubted way vnto the holy clo≈øet of true knowledge and heauenly wi≈øedome. Solomon him≈øelfe the Preacher, a right figure of our Sauiour Chri≈øt, both in his peaceable and glorious kingdome, and in his excellent and ≈øupereminent wi≈øedome, was a man ≈øo prepared of God, to be a mo≈øte notable ≈øtorehou≈øe of Sapience, as no meane of comming thereby in him was wanting. For fir≈øt by naturall towardne≈ø≈øe, good education, ≈øtudie, and other ordinarie meanes, he attained to ≈øuch extraordinarie knowledge, as euen in his tender yeares, which age is mo≈øt ≈øubiect to folly, hee obtained the name and credite of a wi≈øe man before he was a growen man, which not one among tenne thou≈øand euen in his gray heares de≈øerueth to carie. SecoÃÑdly by ≈øpecial grace & diuine reuelatioÃÑ, he was aduauÃÑ ced to the highe≈øt degree of wi≈øedom & vnderstaÃÑding, ≈øo that no man either before him or after him might a≈øpire to the like. And la≈øt of al, before the endighting of this diuine preaching, he had the principal of al his former knowledge, & matter of this ≈øermon confirmed by experience, which among men is counted to haue ≈øo great moment to the obteining of wi≈øedom, as no man lightly is counted wi≈øe, which vnto knowledge & learning hath not ioyned practi≈øe & experience. And although the ≈øame Solomon, by the ≈øecrete & yet mo≈øt wi≈øe iudgement of God, was ≈øuffered for al his wi≈ødom to fal into ≈øuch folly froÃÑ which many thou≈øaÃÑds of gods childreÃÑ, not coÃÑparable to him in knowledge, are pre≈øerued by grace, to ≈øhewe a mo≈øt cleare distinction betwene

And le≈øt of all of this booke, which as it appeareth to haue beene written in the latter ende of his dayes, ≈øo it is thought of many learned men, that it is a te≈øtimonie of his repentance after his fall. The≈øe difficulties are ≈øo well opened, and the true and naturall ≈øen≈øe of the whole text with the right ≈øcope and e ‚Ä¢ de thereof, is ≈øo lea ‚Ä¢ nedly expre≈ø≈øed in the Commentarie, that in mine opinion, no man hath either with more faithfulne≈ø≈øe, ≈øinceritie, or dexteritie, to the ≈øatisfying of the be≈øt l ‚Ä¢ arned, interpreted this booke of Eccle≈øia≈øtes, then this learned man Serranus. Finally, the ≈øame Commentarie‚ñ™ is ≈øo truely tran≈ølated, by one which is a learned Diuine him≈øelfe, and vnder≈øtandeth the worke whereof the Commentarie entreateth (as euery one doeth not that taketh vpon them to tran≈ølate in the≈øe dayes) that the ≈øtudious Reader, by the a≈øsi≈øtance of Gods ≈øpirite ≈øhall vndoubtedly finde ≈øuch frute of his trauaile, as he ≈øhal neuer repent him of his labour be≈øtowed in reading.

div.head: A Praeface of Iohn Serranus vpon the Booke of Solomon, called Eccle≈øia≈øtes, or the Preacher, conteining the Argument and Contents of the Books.
div.p: IN the beginning certain pointes ≈øeeme to be ≈øet down in the way of a Praeface concerning the authoritie ende, method, and v≈øe of this Booke: that the≈øe matters being vnder≈øtood, a more ≈øure and fit way may be made vnto the reading of this mo≈øt excellent Sermon and al≈øo vnto the mo≈øt notable profit which thereby may and ought to come vnto vs.

Becau≈øe that ≈øome doe doubt of the per≈øon of Solomon, it co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eth to pa≈ø≈øe that hereby they take occa≈øion of impea
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng not only the authoritie of this Sermon, but al≈øo of all other his writinges: as if the ≈øame priuiledge of credite and authoritie were not to be giuen vnto them, which is vnto the canonicall Scriptures.

And concerning Solomon, Sundrie opinions concerning the per≈øon of SolomoÃÑ the opinions of the learned are diuer≈øe, and that for mo≈øt weighty con≈øiderations, for in regarde of the notable te≈øtimonies of the goodne≈ø≈øe of God towardes him, ≈øome thinke very well of his ≈øaluation, and holde that there is no doubt to bee made of the ≈øame, albeit he fell into a mo≈øt foule fault, the whiche coulde not make voyde in him the excellent giftes of God: amonge≈øt the whiche, that gift of forgiuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øinnes not to be repented of, and the foundation of the ≈øame, the eternall election of God, obteyneth the fir≈øt place: and therefore that it is not meete that by rea≈øon of ≈øuch a faulte wee ≈øhoulde
doubt of his ≈øaluation, no le≈ø≈øe then of manye other holye men, who≈øe notable faultes are playnely ≈øette downe in the bookes of the ≈øcripture, to the ende that in this mi≈øerye of man his infirmitie and weakene≈ø≈øe we might perceiue the ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈ø≈øe of GOD his mercye, making tho≈øe whome he will,The rea≈øons of them that doubt of the ≈øaluation of Solomon. worthye of eternall life. Some others doe in ≈øuche ≈øorte weigh the circum≈øtances of his mo≈øt greeuous ≈øinne, that they make a very great doubt of his ≈øaluation. For the Scripture doth flatly ≈øet downe, that the heart of Solomon went a≈øide from the God of I≈øraell, and that by foule abu≈øing of the goodne≈ø≈øe of God towards him, as vnto whome God had appeared twi≈øe. Moreouer that this fell oute vnto him at the la≈øt ende almo≈øt of his life, after ≈øo manye and ≈øo great tokens of God his mercye and liberalitie towardes him, in that age, wherein if euer, he ought in deede to haue had bene wi≈øe. That it was al≈øo a ≈øhamefull kinde of fault again≈øt true religion, the which in the faythfull (how≈øoeuer they are ≈øometimes diuer≈ølye carried awaye of their owne lu≈øtes) doth take ≈øuch deepe roote, that it cannot chu≈øe at al times, but bring forth mo≈øt plentiful fruit of reuerence and con≈øtancy. To conclude, that there appeareth no te≈øtimonye of his repentance, and that the renting a≈øunder of the kingdome, which within ≈øhort time followed, doeth teache that God did in no wi≈øe forgiue vnto him this fault.

The minde of the Author touching the ≈øaluation of Solomon.Doubtle≈ø≈øe the fault of Solomon was mo≈øt greeuous, and cannot by any meanes be excu≈øed. For that hee whiche had receiued ≈øuche ≈øinguler giftes of GOD aboute the la≈øte tyme of his lyfe, did of wicked ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe fall awaye vnto Super≈øtition, and to the offence of the church and de≈øtruction of manye, did ≈øette vp publike Monumentes and tokens of that his fallinge awaye, it is a thing ≈øo ≈øhamefull, as is that whiche is mo≈øte ≈øhamefull.

Yet are not the≈øe thinges to this ende ≈øet downe vnto vs, that we ≈øhoulde take vpon vs ≈øo muche authoritie ouer the ≈øecret iudgementes of God, that wee ≈øhoulde conclude ≈øo ≈øingular a per≈øon whome the Lorde woulde haue to be a Figure of his Chri≈øte, to bee appoynted vnto euerla≈øting de≈øtruction, wherefore as it is a pointe of ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe certaynely to pronounce of ≈øo weightye a matter: ≈øo on
the contrarye parte, it is a token of ≈øafene≈ø≈øe and mode≈øtye, in matters of ≈øuche importaunce, and nothing at all appertayning vnto our knowledge, by ≈øtaying oure iudgement to be wi≈øe out of the worde of God, and there out only to gather tho≈øe thinges whiche hee will haue of vs to bee knowne.

The fall then of ≈øo excellente a per≈øonage,To what ende the fal of Solomon is ≈øet forth vnto vs is therefore ≈øet forth vnto vs, that we ≈øhould knowe with howe great carefulne≈ø≈øe we ought to walke betweene the ≈øleightes of the Deuill and ≈øinne, in who≈øe ≈ønares the be≈øt men are ≈øomtimes entrapped: and moreouer that we holilye v≈øe the giftes of God, lea≈øt being puffed vp with them, we bee depriued of his grace, of the which being voyde, and tru≈øting vnto our ≈øtrength, we mu≈øt needes runne headlong into a≈ø≈øured de≈øtruction. Further the expre≈ø≈øe and plaine ≈øetting downe of the faulte of Solomon, appertayneth vnto the Hi≈øtorye following of the ≈øcattering of the kingdome of I≈øraell, the cau≈øe whereof to haue re≈øted in the po≈øterity of Dauid, is playnely proued by this notable ≈øinne of Solomon. But for all this, what≈øoeuer may bee determined eyther of the ≈øaluation or damnation of Solomon,The fal of Solomon is no di≈øcredit to his writings, And why? this notwith≈øtanding mu≈øt be holden for certaintye, that the reproche of his falling awaye or puni≈øhment, maketh nothing at all agayn≈øte his Writinges, and that therefore the authority of them is not hereby le≈ø≈øened nor dimini≈øhed: For as muche as Solomon is not the Author, but onlye the Writer and interpreter of the truth in them conteyned and taughte, for the authoritie of doctrine mu≈øt not hang vpon the per≈øon of the mini≈øter, but altogether vpon the dignitye of the Author. And there is nothing, eyther in this or in the re≈øt of the writinges of Solomon, the which doeth not very well agree with the truth of the Prophets and Apo≈øtles, the which is all one and ≈øimple truth: as with one af≈øured con≈øent, the learned and right minded antiquity hath acknowledged: and the Hebrew copie it ≈øelfe numbred among the holye writinges doeth ≈øufficiently declare.

Therefore I will not make anye longer ≈øtaye in the proofe of that matter, the whiche I ≈øet downe as ≈øure, and agreede vppon: namelye, that the writinges of Solomon, and al≈øo this Sermon, are Canonicall Scripture,
and plainely agree with the truth, and that God would haue them remaine abroade for the edifying of his Ghurch. Onlye we are to begge of him that we may learn the pure and true meaning of this Sermon, and applye it vnto oure profite.

The cheefe and or ≈øcope of this di≈øcour≈øe.Hauing layde downe the authoritie of this Booke, the nexte is, that we ≈øee what is his ≈øcope, that is, his cheefe end, and what is the matter whereof it entreateth. They whiche haue in ≈øuche ≈øorte marked out this end, that they ≈øaye, that Solomon in ≈øetting forth the vanitie of this lyfe (that is to ≈øay of the councels and doinges of men) minded to make vs contented, and to be of quiet mindes in the common affairs and chaunces of this life, that we ≈øhould v≈øe with thanks giuing the creatures of God, which through his ble≈ø≈øing are frankely giuen vnto vs, being contented with thinges pre≈øent, without carefull pen≈øiuene≈ø≈øe for thinges to come: doe in deede ≈øay ≈øomething, but yet doe not plainely ynough ≈øet downe the matter: like as they doe not al≈øo who do thinke the principal point of this worke thus to be diuided: namely that this whole ≈øermon is an auouching of doctrine concerning God his prouidence, and a confuting of ≈øuch things as may be obiected again≈øt it, in the whiche are comfortes to ≈øtrengthen our mindes again≈øt the confu≈øion of thinges, and threatninges again≈øt tho≈øe vnbrideled outrages of men of lewd di≈øpo≈øition, which in this life run ra≈øhlye on on ahead without all feare as it were of puni≈øhment. For the≈øe places are very excellently handled in this di≈øcour≈øe, yet are they not to be iudged the cheefe and principall ende of the ≈øame, but they are fitly applied for the proofe thereof. Now the rules of a true demon≈øtration doe require, that the thing it ≈øelfe be ≈øeuered from the circum≈øtances of the ≈øame. And as the thing or matter is one, ≈øo ought it to be noted oute with one certaine name, and not to be darkelye ≈øhadowed with a long di≈øcour≈øe of many words, lea≈øt that it bee confounded with the circum≈øtaunces of the ≈øame, the whiche were altogether di≈øagreeing from good order of teaching.

Man hath no ≈øtrength at all in heauenly things. 5 Nowe if in bodily and worldly things man his abilitie be ≈øo weake, howe much more weake ≈øhall it be in tho≈øe things which appertaine vnto the life euerla≈øting: in which the powers of man are not onely f√©eble, but al≈øo none at all?

One generation I read the≈øe fowre ver≈øer in one rewe together, becau≈øe that they containe but one certaine and ≈øimple matter, to prooue that fir≈øt and principall propo≈øition concerning the vanitie of the life of man. It is therefore the Second circum≈øtance of that general confutation,The ≈øecond circum≈øtance. taken from the vncertaintie of mankinde, making a compari≈øon with things without life: the which according vnto the ordinances & lawes of their natures, do con≈øtantly keepe their cour≈øes among the ≈øundry ruines and changes of mankind. And it agreeth with the argument and matter alreadie layde open after this maner, How can man reape any certaine fruite and profit of his labours, when as all mankind is carried about hither and thither with a mo≈øt vncertaine motion? For in this vniuer≈øalitie of nature, there are ≈øome certaine
and as it were ≈øet dueties and offices of things, the which are kept a≈ø≈øuredly.The earth. The Earth ≈øtandeth in the middle place of the whole world, as namely the center therof, and the ≈øeat and dwelling place of all liuing creatures.The Sunne. The Sunne hath his ri≈øings and goings downe, the which he keepeth with an vnwearied cour≈øe. The Wind,The Wind. albeit that it haue his pa≈ø≈øages from ≈øundrie partes of the heauen, yet it keepeth the ≈øame con≈øtantly.Riuers. Likewi≈øe the ebbing and flowing of Riuers from ≈øea vnto ≈øea is diuer≈øe and manifold, but yet the ≈øame ≈øuch, that it remaineth all one & con≈øtant. To be ≈øhort all things according vnto the mea≈øure of their creation, haue their ≈øetled and ≈øtedfa≈øt boundes, within the which they keepe them≈øelues: but what is more vn≈øtedfa≈øt then mankinde, what more weake, when as ≈øeuerall and particular men doe dayly die, and are dayly chaunged with a certaine vn≈øtable and vn≈øteadie motion, ≈øo that one age diuer≈ølie followeth another with ≈øundrie chaunges, and there fal out horrible rents in mankind, in the ouerthrowes of cities, kingdomes, families, and in the de≈øtructions of men them≈øelues? Here therefore is a comparing of man with other things created, by who≈øe more ≈øtrong e≈øtate his weakne≈ø≈øe and vncertaintie is more euidently ≈øhewed.

That this is the proper and true meaning of this place,Diuer≈øe expo≈øitions of this place. the circum≈øtances them≈øelues being wi≈øely & diligently weighed, I hope the learned
wil iudge: albeit that it be diuer≈øly expounded by the interpreters. Some thinke that it is a ≈øimilitude taken from the motions of the ≈øunne and of the waters, ≈øo that in the≈øe ≈øhould be ≈øet forth as it were a picture of the vn≈øtedfa≈øtne≈ø≈øe and turning vp and downe of the like mi≈øeries in the affaires of men, the which mi≈øeries can not be letted neither by the deui≈øe, nor wi≈øedome of man, that it ≈øhould be a mo≈øt ≈øimple applying of the ≈øimilitude thus: like as the Sunne and the water haue continuall turnings and goings about, ≈øo the affaires of men together with the mi≈øeries which are mixed with them, are turned vp and downe, neither can the troubles at any hand be letted by the coun≈øaile or wi≈øedome of man. The which doctrine in deede is mo≈øt true, like as the ≈øame is manife≈øt to be ≈øeene in matters both publique and priuate: but the proper circum≈øtances of this place are not agreeable therewith in euerie re≈øpect, as it will appeare vnto him that more heedefully ≈øhall con≈øider the place it ≈øelfe. Others ≈øuppo≈øe that it is no ≈øimilitude, but that the≈øe things are alleaged for them≈øelues, to confirme the general propo≈øition, Al is vanitie, So that Solomon beginneth at the very groundes and cau≈øes of things, that is, with ≈øuch things as by their re≈øtle≈ø≈øe motion declare their vanitie: and as concerning the Sunne they ≈øay that he plainely ≈øpeaketh the≈øe things, the which is the cau≈øe of the generation and de≈øtructioÃÑ of the≈øe
inferior things, and hath great rule ouer them. Others doe in ≈øuch ≈øort con≈øider of the ≈øimilitude, that they apply it after this manner: as the≈øe things continually keepe a ≈øet cour≈øe: ≈øo men are not changed, but alwayes abide in the ≈øame lightnes, curio≈øitie, & re≈øtle≈ø≈øe incon≈øtancie of their affections, and are neuer a whit taught or amended by others examples.The Rabines and Ierom. The Rabines and Ierom transforme and turne all the≈øe things into ≈øtrange allegories, in reckoning vp of the which I would be afraide to abu≈øe the patience of the reader, with the rehear≈øall of ≈øo vaine trifles. Therefore letting pa≈ø≈øe the≈øe things, I nothing doubt but that the wi≈øe reader will be ≈øatisfied with the former expo≈øition, as being the mo≈øt plaine and mo≈øt true. The ≈øumme and effect is, Hereby the vanitie of the life of man doth mo≈øt e≈øpecially appeare, for that whereas all things created, yea ≈øuch as are voide of rea≈øon doe ≈øtedfa≈øtly keepe the ≈øet cour≈øes of their creation, man contrariwi≈øe is often changed euery houre, and his ages doe pa≈ø≈øe away in great diuer≈øitie and alteration.

Now the words are diligently to be weighed and con≈øidered.Dor. The Hebrew word Dor doth ≈øignifie an age, or world, or rather, (as the learned Hebrewes affirme) the dayes which man liueth in this world: the word being deriued of a verbe which ≈øignifieth To dwell: that ≈øo the condition and e≈øtate of man may be ≈øignified, as which namely is ≈øuch, that it hath here no
certaine abiding place, but onely as it were an Inne to lodge in graunted vnto it. For ≈øo man ought to thinke. Men therefore ≈øucceede and come one into the place of another, & ≈øundrie are the alterations of ≈øundry men, & often are the chaunges of mankind, the which are noted by the expre≈ø≈øe words of going and comming: as if the life of maÃÑ were vncertainly to≈ø≈øed vp and downe as it were with flowing and ebbing. Of this ≈øhortnes & incon≈øtancie wherewith mankind is diuer≈øly tumbled about, as there are notable de≈øcriptions eueÃÑ among the heathen writers, ≈øo this life of his e≈øpecially, & daily experieÃÑce, do hereof ≈øet forth true & liuely pictures.

The word ≈øtanding.Again≈øt this vncertaintie of men he ≈øetteth the con≈øtant firmenes and ≈øtayedne≈ø≈øe of the earth, But the earth ≈øtandeth for euer, the word therefore of ≈øtaÃÑnding is matched & ≈øet again≈øt the words of going and comming, by the which we haue ≈øaid the chaunge of mankind to be noted. And he hath verie fitly v≈øed the word of ≈øtanding, ≈øpeaking of the Earth, to ≈øignifie the vnmooueable firmene≈ø≈øe thereof, the which as being the center of the world doth ≈øtand in deede, as in the P≈øal. 104. ver. 5. the true Philo≈øophie doth ≈øay. The earth then ob≈øerueth & keepeth the office inioyned vnto it of God, both to be the mid≈øt of the whole world, and al≈øo the ≈øeat of liuing creatures, when as in the meane ≈øea≈øon not onlie ≈øome particular men doe die, but al≈øo many generations of men, cities, kingdomes, empires,
are diuer≈øly changed.Gnolam, or Hholam. Al≈øo the word Gnolam, (or according vnto ≈øome) Hholam, is knoweÃÑ to ≈øignifie the ≈øpace either of a long time, or el≈øe euerla≈øting. But in this place vnto vs Chri≈øtians it is manife≈øt out of the doctrine of diuine and true Philo≈øophie, that it is not taken for an euerla≈øting time, but onely for a long time: which Philo≈øophie teacheth that the world is not eternall, but that it ≈øhall peri≈øh at his time, albeit the≈øe things al≈øo are ≈øpoken by the way of compari≈øon in regard of the ≈øhortnes of the life of man being as it were but of a dayes continuance, ≈øo that in this re≈øpect the earth may ≈øeeme to haue a certaine eternitie. He maketh mentioÃÑ of the earth in the fir≈øt place, as being better knoweÃÑ vnto vs, & in which do befal tho≈øe changes of maÃÑkind, while≈øt it as a mo≈øt ≈øtrong pillar, remaineth firmly among tho≈øe alterations of worldly things belonging vnto man.

Ver≈ø 5. He ≈øayth al≈øo that the Sunne doth his office as it were his taske,The Sunne. with a con≈øtant and perpetuall race, ≈øo that he neuer wandreth from his appointed cour≈øe. And he v≈øeth a notable & very liuely de≈øcription of his cour≈øe, as if the Sunne did coÃÑtinually runne as it were betweene certaine marks of a race or goale, and did ≈øo ≈øeeke vnto the marke, that ≈øo ≈øoone as he is come thither, he runneth againe the ≈øame race renewing his way, & ≈øo with running too & fro, goeth from the Ea≈øt vnto the We≈øt, & ≈øo

The worde Schoeph ≈øignifieth not onely to breath, but al≈øo as Mercerus hath noted very wel, to looke vpon. And both ≈øignifications agree very well with this place: for the Sunne is ≈øet forth as it were panting and ≈øtriuing to reach vnto his marke: the which he looketh vpon to this ende, as they do which are de≈øirous to come vnto the mark: ≈øuch maner of de≈øcriptions as are eueriwhere to be found in both Greeke and Latine Poets, the which of purpo≈øe I ouerpa≈ø≈øe. The Sunne therefore with ≈øet boundes of his race, and equall di≈øtances of time, pointeth and marketh out the yeere, monethes, dayes, and doeth con≈øtantly continue in this his vocation as it were, when as mankinde euerie foote receiueth diuer≈øe formes, diuer≈øe changes and alterations.

Ver≈øe. 6. I altogether vnder≈øtand the whole ≈øixth ver≈øe of the Winde, The winde. and not of the Sunne, as other interpreters doe. Namely, the i≈ø≈øuings forth of the winds as contrarie one to another, out of the foure quarters of the world: the which cannot be ≈øayd of the Sunne, the which is carried about from the Ea≈øt vnto the We≈øt, through the force of the fir≈øt mouer or firmament, and with a peculiar motion of his owne, proceedeth from the We≈øt vnto the Ea≈øt: and goeth not into the South or North. And

Doubtle≈ø≈øe it is a thing mo≈øt true, that the winde is not euerie beating of the aire, and that the diuer≈øe names according vnto the terming of them by men, were not giuen in vaine: but that the powers and qualities of the windes are diuer≈øe and contrarie, the which doe blowe from certaine and ≈øet places, and do order their bla≈øtes with a certaine greater power ≈øome one then an other: as is ≈øhewed, P≈øal. 104. and 107. The which miracles of the winds, the writings of the Philo≈øophers: do ≈øhew not onely vnto the learned: but al≈øo the mo≈øt euident effectes doe make apparant vnto the vn≈økilfull. But the more deepe & through di≈øcour≈øe of this matter I leaue vnto the ≈øchooles of the Philo≈øophers.

He ≈øayth al≈øo that the VVaters doe con≈øtantly keepe the cour≈øe appointed them by God:The waters. and that in ≈øuch ≈øort, that the riuers doe ri≈øe out of the ≈øea, and returne into the ≈øea againe, with a certaine vncea≈øing pa≈ø≈øage. The exqui≈øite and
exact treatize of the waters, like as of the winds I turne ouer vnto the Philo≈øophers: neither doe I bring ≈øtraunge doctrine into the≈øe writings, yet is it the duetie of an Interpreter at lea≈øt wi≈øe to note by the way, ≈øuch things as are ≈øpoken by the way.Ari≈øtotle his opinion concerning the beginning of riuers. Ari≈øtotle noteth this to be the originall and beginning of riuers, namely that the aire thickened in the earth by rea≈øon of colde doeth re≈øolue and turne into water: and that it doeth not onelie drawe out water in the holes of the earth, that it may ≈øpring forth from thence, but al≈øo to mini≈øter and yelde continually newe matter, for riuers to come thereof.The opinion of old Phil ‚Ä¢
≈øophers. Yet this was the opinion of olde Philo≈øophers concerning the beginning of riuers, That they both ari≈øe out of the ≈øea through ≈øecrete and priuie pa≈ø≈øages of the earth, and doe flowe againe and runne into the ≈øea, which appeareth both out of diuer≈øe places of Plato, Plato. and al≈øo out of the flatte wordes of Ari≈øtotle, finding fault with this opinion, which Solomon doeth here ≈øet downe, but that this la≈øt opinion is more agreeable vnto rea≈øon then the former, it is manife≈øt by plaine rea≈øon: for except the water of the ≈øea, were conueighed as it were by certaine ≈øecrete pipes through the earth, and except all the water of all the riuers, which runneth into the ≈øea, did againe come forth of the ≈øea: who doth not ≈øee that it can by no meanes by cho≈øen, but that the water, if it were but only of the

Mo≈øes doubtle≈ø≈øe a true teacher of true Philo≈øophie, teacheth that God woulde haue the waters gathered into one place, and the drie land to appeare: of the which principle of naturall Philo≈øophie wee ought not to ≈øeeke any better Interpreter, then the holie Gho≈øt him≈øelfe, who in Dauid P≈øal. 104. ≈øayth, That the earth at the first was couered with the waters as with a garment: but that it departed at the certaine commaundement of God, and that there were appoynted vnto it certaine boundes, within the which it ≈øhould keepe it ≈øelfe, and that the flouds and fountaynes doe ≈øpring from thence, for the diuer≈øe v≈øes of liuing creatures, yea and e≈øpecially for man him≈øelfe. Que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe, it is manife≈øt by the verie principles of nature, that the earth as the heauie≈øt element, by the law and ordinance of her nature, ought to take the lowe≈øt part of the whole world: and therefore that the water, as next vnto the earth in heauine≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould al≈øo haue po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the place next vnto the earth, that is to ≈øay the face of the whole earth, vnle≈ø≈øe the peculiar commandement of God the workma≈øter had ≈øtepped in betweene: by the force & power of which commaundement ≈øome part of the earth ≈øhoulde remaine drie, from the waters, and ≈øhould afoord a place for all liuing creatures, & for man e≈øpecially, to dwel in, for
who≈øe ≈øake all liuing creatures were created. Nowe that the ≈øea might fulfill this commandement of God, there were made pa≈ø≈øages and as it were pipes vnderneath the earth, by the which plentie of water might be conueighed, and might al≈øo be giuen for the v≈øe of liuing creatures. That this is the rea≈øon of the conueighing of riuers as it were by pipes vnderneath the earth, the which come out of the ≈øea, and returne againe into the ≈øea,An ab≈øurditie. the ab≈øurditie of the contrarie doctrine ≈øeemeth for to confirme and prooue. For who will beleeue, that of the aire thickened in the holow pa≈ø≈øages of the earth, ≈øo great plentie of water can be yeelded, that it is ≈øufficient to make ≈øo many and ≈øo mightie riuers? But this is vnto me a mo≈øt ≈øtrong rea≈øon, why I doe beleeue the originall and beginning of riuers to be ≈øuch,No naturall Philo≈øopher comparable vnto Solomon. becau≈øe Solomon ≈øayth ≈øo: the be≈øt naturall Philo≈øopher of all Philo≈øophers farre away in my iudgement: who≈øe Phi≈øickes & naturall Philo≈øophie if they were extant and abroad, I would preferre them before all the writings of Plato and Ari≈øtotle. There are therefore certaine and ≈øet offices of the Earth, The Sunne, The VVindes, The riuers, and all other things created haue their proper and appointed workes and ≈øeruice, in which they are con≈øtantly occupied: but both ≈øeuerall and particular men doe dayly die, and ≈øo many and ≈øo great changes doe fall out euen
vnto mankinde it ≈øelfe, that he ≈øeemeth by no meanes to be able to ≈øtand: the which doubtle≈ø≈øe is a mo≈øt certaine argument and token of his incon≈øtancie and vanitie.

div.head: The doctrine.
div.p: 1 In that he ≈øetteth before vs ≈øo notable a picture of our vncertaintie,Vaine is the endeuour of man to continue the memorie of his name vpon earth. it appeareth how vaine the ≈øtudie of man is to haue them≈øelues and their name that mu≈øt die, to continue many ages, the which vanitie as the holy Gho≈øt doth ≈øharpelie rebuke, ≈øo are there manie notable examples of God his iudgement again≈øt it, not onely in per≈øons, and families, in the common cour≈øe of life, but al≈øo in famous Monarchies the which albeit they were grounded vpon great foundations, yet are they ≈øo fallen, that hard and ≈øcar≈øely there are remaining any tokens of them. Such chaunges and ouerthrowes the Earth hath ≈ø√©ene, the Sunne hath ≈ø√©ene, the Riuers and other things created haue ≈ø√©ene, the which tho≈øe Gyantes with their expeditions haue wearied: yet they are dead, the≈øe continue euen vnto this day.

2 Of like vanitie doe men offend,It is vaine for men that haue no a≈ø≈øurance of their life, to make accounts as if they had a long time to liue. when as being yet aliue they certainlie determine of things to come for many yeeres: when as they can not make accountes in ≈øo great vncertaintie of life, by any meanes of one day, which cleare ≈øightedne≈ø≈øe of the wit of man, the holy Gho≈øt accu≈øeth of follie or madne≈ø≈øe: and experience doth plentifully teache the ≈øame accu≈øation to be true: that
we ≈øhould betimes learne to liue for the pre≈øent, and commit all our affaires vnto the prouidence of God, and ≈øo order our life, as if we ≈øhould die to day or to morrow.

3 That which he ≈øayeth of the firmene≈ø≈øe and ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈ø≈øe of things without life, is diligently to be marked. Howe manie chaunges doe happen euen in things without life, famous examples doe declare.The cau≈øes of the chaunges that fall out in the worlde are not to be a≈øcribed vnto fortune, nor yet vnto nature ≈øimplie. The cau≈øes of ≈øuch chaunges are by no meanes to be layde vpon fortune, as ≈øome vngodlie per≈øons doe, pretending for the excu≈øe of their fooli≈øh opinions a certaine madne≈ø≈øe voyde of all Philo≈øophie: (for what is more farre from the knowledge of Philo≈øophie, then to take awaie Cau≈øe out of the world?) neither are they ≈øimplie to be attributed vnto nature: ≈øauing ≈øo farre as nature, is a fellowe worker and ≈øeruant of God the workemai≈øter. There fall out then great alterations in the things them≈øelues, either by Waters, Fires, Earthquakes, or other greater ca≈øualties. But yet nature her ≈øelfe, among tho≈øe particular chaunges, from the time of her creation euen vnto this day, is, and ≈øhall be pre≈øerued, ≈øo long as it ≈øhall plea≈øe the Workema≈øter: who hath giuen vnto it, if it be compared with particular things, in a maner an immortall and euerla≈øting firmene≈ø≈øe, but yet the ≈øame at his will and plea≈øure whollie, as al≈øo the more ≈øounder Philo≈øophers doe acknowledge, who as they affirme the world to be created by God: ≈øo al≈øo they
≈øay that there was giuen vnto it an immortalitie (but ≈øuch as was renued by God & wholy fitted by the plea≈øure and will of ye Workma≈øter) that looke by what power the world was knitte and compact together, by the ≈øame likewi≈øe it is to be di≈ø≈øolued, when, and after what maner it ≈øhall plea≈øe the Workmai≈øter.This place doeth not prooue the world to be euerla≈øting. Away therefore with tho≈øe prophane Smatterers in Philo≈øophie, who out of this place fal≈øly vnder≈øtood, doe fondlie maintaine that the worlde is ≈øayd to be euerla≈øting.

4 It is more ouer to be noted in that ≈øame good order of nature,The con≈øtant cour≈øe of things naturall, condemneth the incon≈øtaÃÑt lightnes of man. and in the con≈øtant ob≈øeruation of the ≈øame, howe great reproch is as it were with a burning yron marked in our lightne≈ø≈øe. All creatures do their dutie, they k√©epe the lawes appointed vnto them without wearine≈ø≈øe, they obey their Maker. Onely man, for who≈øe ≈øake the world was made, rebelleth again≈øt God, & breaking the lawes of his creation, is carried away headlong into all outrage of ≈øinne: according as it is ca≈øt into the t√©eth not onely of the ra≈øcall ≈øort, but euen of the verie ≈øame that were taught by the voyce of God, by the Prophet, The Oxe and the A≈ø≈øe haue knowen the crib, &c.

5 This furthermore is to be remembred,God can alter the cour≈øe of nature. that this certaine order of nature is in ≈øuch re≈øpect and ≈øo farre con≈øtant and ≈øtedfa≈øt, that God notwith≈øtanding, the maker and Lorde thereof, may chaunge it at his plea≈øure, accordingly as he is di≈øpo≈øed either to execute his iudgementes vpon

div.head: The doctrine.
div.p: 1 They no doubt are true teachers,Who are true teachers. who doe ≈øoberlie and earne≈øtlie ioyne practize vnto contemplation of things and knowledge of the ≈øame, that is, which are per≈øwaded and a≈ø≈øured of that which they teache, by certaine experience. Knowledge without the gift to v≈øe it, doth little auaile.3 Here out al≈øo we doe learne, that knowledge doth little or nothing at all profit, vnle≈ø≈øe there be rea≈øon and power to v≈øe it: therfore the ≈øame Apo≈øtle ≈øayde vnto Timothie, Con≈øider what I ≈øay, God giue thee vnder≈øtanding in al things. For the be≈øt men,The be≈øt men haue giuen them≈øelues vnto the ≈øtudie of Philo≈øophie. abandoning the de≈øire of glory and of monie, and counting all other thinges as nothing, by giuing them≈øelues vnto the contemplation and ≈øtudie of the nature of thinges, haue alwayes thought that they followed the be≈øt kinde of life, and that

div.head: The Doctrine.
div.p: Solomon doth not ≈øimply coÃÑ demn wi≈ødom.1. 2. Prudence or the wi≈ødome of man is a great

div.head: The doctrine.
div.p:

3. 4. The ≈øeconde degr√©e is, wherein the true

≈øtrong and ≈øounde aun≈øwere again≈øt this backbiting of the fle≈øhe,An≈øwere vnto the former contrarieties. this we oughte e≈øpeciallye and principallye to holde, that the a≈ø≈øurance and full per≈øwa≈øion of Fayth is certayne, and therefore certayne, becau≈øe that it looketh not vppon tho≈øe thinges which are ≈øubiecte, and lie open vnto the eyes of the body, but vpon the thinges which are not ≈ø√©ene with the eyes. Let this rea≈øon therefore very greatlye preuayle with vs, and ≈øo let this be a≈ø≈øured and certaine,The fulne≈ø≈øe of our felicity is to be looked for in heauen that that ≈øpiritual inheritaunce is al≈øo ≈øpiritually to be e≈øt√©emed: and that ≈øo farre, that according vnto the promi≈øe of the true God, is fulfilled in vs abundantly. div.head: The doctrine.
div.p:

Their dignitie and excellencie therfore is ≈øingular, whome God maketh mini≈øters of ≈øo worthie and weightie matters, and he will al≈øo haue theÃÑ enioy mo≈øt great & notable priuileges aboute the condition of other men. 2. div.p: 1. Haue regard vnto, or keepe] The tenoure of the matter in hande doeth altogether require, that the beginning of the fifte chapiter bee taken from hence. The fir≈øt an≈øwere vnto the former ‚Ä¢ ntation.15. And I pray≈øed, &c.) The fir≈øt an≈øwere, that we mu≈øt not curiou≈øly giue ouer our ≈øelues vnto the≈øe cogitations and thoughtes, but that
nothing is better, nothing is more excellent (in as much as no man can rightly giue a cau≈øe of the≈øe di≈øorders, wherewith the lyfe of man is troubled) then ridding our minds out of the≈øe cares, cherefully to v≈øe the benefites of God: & committing our affaires vnto the prouidence of GOD, that we go not about in any ca≈øe curiou≈øly to prie into the ≈øecretes of thinges vnknowne, as namely to ≈øeeke why the Lord dealeth after this and this maner. Therefore that it is the be≈øt ≈øoberly to con≈øider of the≈øe matters: and at no hande ≈øo to behaue our ≈øelues, that by rea≈øon of the too vehement or earne≈øt conceiuing of them, we be bereft of the fruit of God his benefites. This is the fir≈øt an≈øwere.

16. Therefore, &c) The ≈øeconde aun≈øwere, if,The ≈øeconde Aun≈øwere. ≈øayth he, thou ≈øearch after the thinges that fall out vnto men in this life, and the cau≈øes of the ≈øame, albeit that thou bend all the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of thy witte vnto the contemplation and ≈øtudye of ≈øo greate ≈øecretes, employ all thy labour and diligence, and defraude or keepe thy ≈øelfe from ≈øleepe, and other nece≈ø≈øary helpes for the mayntainaunce of this life: yet ≈øhall thy mind be altogether a≈øtonied, and thy enterpri≈øe of ≈øearching ≈øhall be in vain. Therefore he forbiddeth that wee bee not wi≈øe according vnto the iudgement of the rea≈øon of man: but oute of the word of God, which is the true and ≈øounde wi≈øedome. In a worde, hee ≈øignifyeth, that it ‚Ä¢ annot po≈ø≈øible bee, that we ≈øhould vnder≈øtand
the cau≈øes of tho≈øe thinges, the whiche in the common life of man, doe after ≈øo ≈øundrie ≈øortes fall out: yea and moreouer that it is a mo≈øt vayne thing, to vexe our minde about the ≈øearching out of them too curiou≈øly: but that we mu≈øt ≈øtay and re≈øt vppon the worde of God, from whence true oracles or aun≈øweres mu≈øt be ≈øet and taken.

div.head: The ninth Chapter.
div.p: The thirde an≈øwere.1. Surely I haue, &c.) The third an≈øwere, although it be ≈øo, that is to ≈øay, that the rea≈øons can not be yeelded of the≈øe troubles and di≈øorders: yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe we are to hold for certaintie, that all thinges are by God mo≈øt wi≈øely gouerned. He ≈øayth by way of Preface that hee diligently trauailed about the ≈øearching oute of all this matter: by which enquirie he ≈øayth, that hee learned, That the iu≈øt, &c.) That is to ≈øaye, that GOD hath a ≈øinguler and an e≈øpeciall care of good and godlye men. Not as if GOD hath ca≈øt away the care of other men: but hee diligentlye declareth that whiche was in controuer≈øitie, and wherevpon all the di≈øcour≈øe was taken.

Who they are whom Solomon calleth iu≈øt and in what re≈øpect. The iu≈øt according to the v≈øe of the ≈øcripture he calleth the faithfull: whome God namelye of his meere grace accounteth for iu≈øt, as being he that iu≈øtifieth the vngodlie, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, while≈øt he imputeth vnto them their faith
in him vnto righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and in whom al≈øo he imprinteth the te≈øtimonies of righteou≈ønes, that is to ≈øay, of a pure and innocent or giltles life, as the pledges of their election. Hee calleth them Wi≈øe, becau≈øe they are enlightened with the true light of true wi≈øedome, that is to ≈øaye, with the knowledge of God and with Godline≈ø≈øe, the which is true and ≈øounde wi≈øedome. This is one cheefe point of this whole an≈øwere, yet he adioyneth a new and diligent de≈øcriptioÃÑ of the wauering & vncertaine condition, and e≈øtate of the life of maÃÑ. And yet (for ≈øo I expouÃÑd the particle gam) man knoweth not neither loue nor hatred, &c. that is to ≈øay, Although it be mo≈øte certaine that God hath an e≈øpeciall care for the ≈øaluation of the faithfull, yet ≈øuch is the cour≈øe of thinges falling oute vnto men in this life, that it cannot bee iudged by their outwarde ≈øhewe and appearance whome God loueth, or whome he hateth, for there is euery where ≈øuch a coÃÑfu≈øed ≈øhufling of things together, that ther is all together all one ende, and the ≈øame common vnto all men both godlie and vngodlye: and when as lewd per≈øons haue pa≈ø≈øed all their lyfe in wickedne≈ø≈øe, yet at length they go vnto death, as vnto the la≈øt ende of thinges: wherewith they are taken awaye, like vnto other men, the which ≈øeeme with one dart of Death to bee ≈ølayne quite. I reade al this in one contexte and tenour together, from this fir≈øt ver≈øe vnto the end of all the ≈øixte ver≈øe: and thinke
this to be the true meaning of the≈øe wordes. The ≈øumme is:How≈øoeuer things goe in the world, yet the prouidence of God watcheth continually ouer the faithfull. albeit the outwarde ≈øhewe of things do ca≈øt a certaine infinite or endles confu≈øion before the eyes of man his rea≈øon, yet that this is ≈øure and certaine, that the prouidence of God doth continually watch ouer the ≈øaluation and ≈øafetie of the faithfull. But the wordes with an exqui≈øite and great garni≈øhing of figures, are more diligently to bee examined. He ≈øayeth: that man knoweth not either loue or hatred of all things which are before them, that is to ≈øaye: It can by no meanes be iudged, by the difference of tho≈øe thinges, the which ≈øundrye wayes fall out in this life, what men are acceptable vnto God or no? for the wordes loue & hatred are to be referred vnto God and not vnto men, that is to ≈øaye, What men God loueth or hateth. Therefore the olde tran≈ølator hath not tran≈ølated them well, Man knoweth not whether he be worthie of loue or hatred. The Sophi≈øters in deede halfe Pelagians (to ≈øpeake mo≈øt mode≈øtly & gently of them) haue lewdly corrupted this place,Again≈øt the Papi≈øts corrupting this place. to bring in a doubting, that is to ≈øay, a tormenting of the con≈øciences of men: as if the faithfull ought not to bee certainly per≈øuaded in their con≈øciences, that they albeit neuer ≈øo vnworthie, are loued of God for Chri≈øt his ≈øake, when as by faith the which hee al≈øo giueth vnto them, they lay holde vpon his free promi≈øes: nor contrariwi≈øe, that ≈øinne is mo≈øt greatly hated of GOD: but that men
ought to ≈øtand at this point, that they ≈øtagger and wauer in doubting. The which doctrine ≈øhaketh the foundation of true religion: for it taketh away the efficacie and force of the promi≈øes and threatnings of God. The verie principall and in deede effectuall effect of faith is, that per≈øua≈øion or tru≈øt, whereby wee a≈ø≈øuredly beleeue the forgiuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øinnes, and that the ≈øpirite of God is a witne≈ø≈øe vnto our ≈øpirit, that we are the ≈øonnes of God, & do approch without feare vnto the throne of grace. The which full a≈ø≈øurance or tru≈øt, hee that taketh away from faith, doeth altogither weaken and de≈øtroy faith, and ≈øo farre as in him lyeth, maketh God a lyar.As God is true in his promi≈øes, ≈øo is he al≈øo in his threatenings. Nowe as wee are to beleeue that God is true in his promi≈øes, ≈øo mu≈øt wee al≈øo doubtle≈ø≈øe beleeue that hee hath the ≈øame trueth in his threatenings: and therefore that hee is greatly offended euen with his children, when they ≈øinne, that with this bitt we may be helde backe from wickedne≈ø≈øe, and robbe not God his prouidence of one of her eyes. For God is both iu≈øt and al≈øo mercifull: and wee mu≈øt ≈øtedfa≈øtly agree vnto his worde, wherein we are taught that wee are the ≈øonnes of God, and that the euerla≈øting foundation of oure faith ≈øtandeth in ≈øuch ≈øort that it cannot bee ≈øhaken, vpon his free good will: al≈øo that God is an enimie vnto ≈øinne: that we may feare him becau≈øe he is good. This is a true doctrine, & agreeable vnto faith, the which Sophi≈øters do
impurely defile: and they fouly corrupt this place, when as it doth manife≈øtly preach of the prouidence of God, again≈øt ≈øuch as denye his prouidence becau≈øe of the outwarde appearance of thinges, for that it goeth ill with the good, and well with the bad: and becau≈øe of the≈øe ≈øightes or di≈øorder they do fal away from God. For by the≈øe wordes, All things before them, all tho≈øe things are ≈øignified, which befall vnto this life, and are apparant before the eyes of men: by the outward con≈øideration of which thinges cannot bee gathered, whome God doeth loue or hate. And why he ≈øo ≈øayth, he yeldeth by and by a rea≈øon.

2 All things fall out &c. That is, there is all one end vnto the Godly, and vnto the vngodly. Yet doeth hee wi≈øely de≈øcribe and ≈øet out the difference of the men betweene them ≈øelues, vnto whome, notwith≈øtanding there is a common ende.He that ≈øacrificeth. Hee calleth Him that ≈øacrificeth, him that diligently giueth him≈øelfe vnto the ≈øeruice and wor≈øhip of GOD, and doeth holily keepe the ≈øeruice and ordinances ≈øet downe by the lawe. Contrariwi≈øe, hee calleth him that Sacrificeth not, ≈øuch a one, as contemneth the wor≈øhip of GOD. The which is a token of a godle≈ø≈øe & an impure heart. He calleth him a Sinner, according vnto the common v≈øe of the ≈øcripture, which is a man of notorious lewdne≈ø≈øe and wickedne≈ø≈øe: Him that ≈øweareth, hee termeth ≈øuch a
one, as abu≈øeth an othe by ≈øwearinge either prophanely,Him that ≈øweareth. and when there is no neede (as tho≈øe doe the which doe ≈øpice their talke with bla≈øphemies, as if it were with ornamentes of Rhethorike) or by for≈øwearing in an earne≈øt matter. Which is a ≈øigne of lewde and extreme wickedne≈ø≈øe.

And hee ≈øayeth, that there rangeth ≈øo great di≈øorder among men, that there is all one ende vnto all men. And that men take ≈øuch a common cour≈øe of life, as if there were no feelinge after death, and that there ≈øhoulde bee no puni≈øhment at all for ≈øinnes, as if, after that they haue pa≈ø≈øed ouer this life, they care not howe, when the race thereof is runne, they mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe vnto death, as vnto a common nece≈øsitie, whiche ≈øhoulde ≈øwallowe vp, and blotte out for euer the memoriall of all men, who≈øoeuer they are. Hee marketh this prophane cogitation or ≈øurmize with expre≈ø≈øe wordes: The heart of men is full of euill, & madne≈ø≈øe is in their heart, in their life: and after this vnto the dead. And in the two nexte ver≈øes hee paynteth out the tryumph of death ouer all kinde of men.

4. and 5. For vnto euery one.] The effects of life & death compared togither. He compareth the effectes of death and life togither, vnto the garni≈øhing and amplyfying of the matter. Him that is ioyned vnto all them that are aliue, hee calleth euerye liuing man, whiche hath the v≈øe and benefite of life, of howe lowe
or ba≈øe condition or degree ≈øoeuer he be. Him he ≈øayth to be better then a dead man, who≈øoeuer at any hand he be, and in howe great dignitie ≈øoeuer hee did ≈øometimes excell, v≈øing a prouerbe: That a liuing dog, is better then a dead Lyon. The v≈øe of which prouerbe ≈øerueth to ≈øhewe the excellencie and commoditie of life. Vnto the ≈øame purpo≈øe appertaine the wordes of the next ver≈øe,Death vanqui≈øheth man and al things belonging vnto man. of the which this is the plaine and true meaning, that all things the which do belong vnto men, yea & al≈øo men them ≈øelues e≈øpecially (if the outward ≈øhewe & appearance be looked vnto) do altogether dy, and are taken away by death. And it is a trimme kinde of ≈øpeach ≈øea≈øoned with a fine figure: that Loue, Hatred, Enuie, and other affections, who≈øe dominion was large and wide, while≈øt they were aliue is extingui≈øhed and put cleane out, with death and al≈øo with the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øers of them, and that there ≈øhall bee no profite of them before the chiefe Iudge, as vnto whom accounts mu≈øt be giuen of their whole life. And that this is a di≈øorder of things falling out in this life vnto men experience it ≈øelfe doth ≈øufficiently and abundantly teach. What then mu≈øt wee doe among ≈øo great outrages?

7 Go, eat.] The≈øe things he noted in the beginning of this place at the 15. ver≈øe of the eight Chapter.Curio≈øitie altogither vnprofitable. Nowe hee gathereth a generall conclu≈øion of the ≈øame, and that notably ≈øhewing the whole matter, the effect is, That curio≈øitie
is altogither vaine and hurtfull, that it doeth vexe and torment the minde, becau≈øe of the outrages and confu≈øions of this life: that it is better with a ≈øober and cheerefull minde to v≈øe the benefites of God, and diligently to apply our ≈øelues euery man vnto his calling, and to be≈øtowe the powers of our minde about the di≈øcharging of it faithfully and painfully, while≈øt that by meanes of life & occa≈øion we may, and to ≈øtay vpon the ble≈øsing of God, whereupon doubtle≈ø≈øe all the happie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of all things doe depend. Go therefore, ≈øayeth he &c. that is to ≈øay: Torment and vexe not thy mind too much with the≈øe cares: but rather v≈øe and inioye things pre≈øent with a≈ø≈øured quietnes of minde: as for thinges falling out vnto men in this life the which thou can≈øt not helpe, ≈øuffer them to pa≈ø≈øe and fleete awaye, as they come. And he doeth ≈øet foorth and garni≈øh this plain ≈øentence verie finely with diuer≈øe words, Go, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, rid thy ≈øelfe out of the≈øe mad cares: for what neede is there, and what doth it profit thee to bu≈øie thy ≈øelf about many matters? As it was by Chri≈øt obiected vnto Martha too bu≈øilie occupying her ≈øelfe about her hou≈øholde. Eat, drinke, that is to ≈øaye: v≈øe and enioy freely the commodities of this life. To this purpo≈øe perteine the≈øe wordes,

8 At all times let thy garmentes be white, and oyle vppon &c.] By which wordes he ≈øignifyeth that wee mu≈øt leaue nothing vndone for the
enioying of a merrie and plea≈øant life, namely, that cleanne≈ø≈øe and finene≈ø≈øe is not to be ouerpa≈ø≈øed,Again≈øt ≈øuch as make an allegorie of this place. the which doeth make meate & drinke more plea≈øant. For where as ≈øome do allegorically expounde the≈øe wordes, of the ≈øimplicitie of the heart, it is true I confe≈ø≈øe, and agreeable vnto faith, but yet it is from the right meaning of this place. Finally, ≈øaith Solomon:

9 Liue thy life, &c.] that is ≈øo ≈øaye, enioy thou the commodities of this life with a≈ø≈øured and ≈øound contentedne≈ø≈øe of minde:A good wife is one of the greate≈øt ble≈ø≈øings that mai befall vnto a man in this life. with the wife, then e≈øpecially, when as God hath giuen thee a wife meete for thee, and fit for thy mind and manners: then the which benefite, among the ble≈øsings which appertaine vnto this life, nothing is better, nor more deare, nothing more profitable nor more plentiful vnto al the parts of life. All the dayes, &c. If thou ≈øhalt haue obteined this benefit at the hands of God, v≈øe it as a pa≈øport to wander ouer the race of this mi≈øerable life:A proui≈øo concerning the v≈øe of the things pertaining vnto this life. & dwel ≈øo with thy ≈øelfe, that thou haue at home with thee as hou≈øhold ge≈øtes, coÃÑ tentednes, & ioy of mind. And he will haue the v≈øe of all the≈øe things pertaining vnto life thus
far to be free, that always a nece≈ø≈øary exception be vnder≈øtood, namely ≈øo far as God hath created them, to be v≈øed of the faithful ≈øoberly, and with thanks giuing. For the wi≈øeman in this place ≈øpeaketh of the lawful v≈øe of things. This moreouer mu≈øt be ≈øupplied out of the Apo≈øtle, That we fa≈øten not our affection neither vpon the getting of the≈øe things, nor vpon the v≈øing of them, nor vpon the forgoing of them: but that we po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them as not po≈ø≈øe≈øsing theÃÑ, that we want & abound according vnto the ple≈øure of the lord: & finally, that we be always redie to liue & dye vnto him, and not vnto our ≈øelues. Now he adioyneth a new circum≈øtance:

10 Al that &c. He ≈øignifieth,A pre≈øeÃÑt remedie for the auoiding of the wearine≈ø≈øe of this life. that it is a mo≈øt pre≈øent remedy for the auoiding of the tediou≈ønes of this life, that euery one of vs diligently follow his own vocation, & imploy all the powers of his minde about the di≈øcharging of it faithfully. For there is nothing more bu≈øie than is idlenes, the which filleth the mind with vain cogitations, as if there were not alreadie pre≈øeÃÑt occa≈øion to occupy it about,They be the wordes of the Poet Horace, by the which he noteth the follie of ≈øuch, as letting go the pre≈øent occa≈øion to doe good, idly mu≈øe vpon other matters. & to followe ≈øome trade: for ≈øo ≈øaith he: The hu≈øband man or countrie man waiteth vntill the riuer leaue running. Contrariwi≈øe, the mind being occupyed about ≈øome certaine bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, is not cumbred with tho≈øe curious wearine≈ø≈øes of ≈øearchinge after needele≈ø≈øe matters. All that which thou ≈øhalt finde, hee ≈øayeth not that wee mu≈øt doe what≈øoeuer wee li≈øt or plea≈øe, but what≈øoeuer
≈øhall appertaine vnto our calling. And hee giueth to vnder≈øtand that there are ≈øundry ≈øortes of callings, but that euery man ought to bee occupied in his owne calling, and that ≈øayeth hee: According vnto the power, that is, as thou art able, and according vnto the mea≈øure, the which God the vpright arbitrer and di≈øpo≈øer of his owne giftes, hath imparted vnto thee. For this is a true and certaine rule for all callings:A nece≈ø≈øarie rule for all callings. Not to be wi≈øe aboue that we ought to be wi≈øe, but to be wi≈øe vnto ≈øobrietie, vnto euerie one according as God hath imparted the mea≈øure of faith. Hee addeth: Becau≈øe there is no worke &c. In the graue whither thou goe≈øt. His meaning is not (as the mad Epicures do ≈øay) that there is no ≈øen≈øe or feeling after death, & that therefore the whole man is de≈øtroyed: but this hee meaneth, that we mu≈øt labour in our calling, while≈øt it is day, before the darkne≈ø≈øe of death ouertake vs, in the which there ≈øhalbe no time to worke. In a worde, he willeth vs diligently to followe our calling, and in it to v≈øe faithfull and painful labour, and diligently to take the opportunitie and fit times to doe well, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith: VVhilest we haue fit time, let vs do good, that God may find vs labouring in his worke. But how farre, and with what minde wee ought to worke, he now further teacheth.

11 I turned, &c.] The≈øe wordes do plainly agree with them that went nexte before, yet they containe an excellent garni≈øhing of the
whole doctrine: That the affaires of men are gouerned by the prouidence of god, Nothing hath good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe with out the ble≈ø≈øing of God. the which doctrin is the foundation and principall point of this place. The ≈øumme is: That all the endeuours of men are in vaine, vnle≈ø≈øe the ble≈øsing of God be with them, the which onely is the effectuall way in deede for the doing of things happily, or with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and (as one ≈øayeth) the perfection of all well doing. By the words of Turning about and ≈øeeing, he ≈øheweth that the ≈øame thing was confirmed by experience, the which he had diligently marked. That the race is not vnto the ≈øwift: Hee teacheth in expre≈ø≈øe wordes, that the i≈ø≈øues & falling out of things are not in the hand, or indu≈øtrie of man, no not in tho≈øe things the which appertaine vnto this life, as Ieremie ≈øayeth: I knowe Lord, that the way of man is not in man. Not as if a man were a blocke, and that there were no election or choy≈øe of will in them: (the whiche politike men call the beginning of doing) but becau≈øe GOD doeth bende the ≈øame purpo≈øe of the will of man, into what waye hee will, and doeth gouerne and di≈øpo≈øe the i≈ø≈øues and fallinge out of thinges with an ab≈øolute and chiefe rule and power. Hee teacheth therefore that all the ≈øea≈øons of our whole life are without man,All things pertaining vnto this life ar gouerned by God. and con≈øtantly gouerned by GOD: And of purpo≈øe reckoneth vp ≈øuch thinges as are more notable in our life, the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of thinges valiantly atchiued, warres,
the way to gouerne our families, riches and wealth, knowledge: all which he denyeth to be in the power of man.
